  I intend going to the village in the morning to see Rev. Ed. Davies and write this to take to the mail. Anna says your morning to write home every week and when she told me she wondered whether you would be so faithful I said if we write, he will I think. So tho' I am tired I will not let this oppertunity slip. Mr. Owen, the printer is sick with typhoid fever and Mr. Davies is troubled about the setting of the of the Cenhadwr so he asked David Price to see if I could help a little with it. I am therefore going to try if it does not rain in the morning I meant to write but it got too late. It was such a bright fair day yesterday that I was tempted and did a large washing. Today I ironed. Anna began a little hour cleaning today. She looked over several cups from our bedroom clothespress and she said I wish John Eddie could be home a week more we would make quick work house cleaning. But we must do the best we can. I enjoy feeding and caring for the hens, but it seems most too confining for them these warm days - I knocked off the board from above the door of the chickery today - there are slats across and that will give them more light and air

There is still a great-deal of that snow drift left outside and in their yard. I noticed today that the little pickets that belong on the lower edge of the roof are down. If we had only noticed it when you were home - perhaps I can fix it. We are having very pleasant weather now and it seems very nice to see the snow go so quickly and the birds in every nook and corner picking up after the snow - John Williams had just been in  - you remember when he came to collect for the Bible Society - I gave him five half dollars which you had got in exchange when you paid for your rubbers. the other half dollar I kept and I sent it with Mr. Prichard to buy feed for our hens. It was plugged and he could not pass it so he brought it home and I took it down to David Jones. He remembered your buying the rubbers of him and his giving you several half dollars in change out of a $5 bill and he gave me good money instead because I said I had no other change in my purse besides what you had given me. You will please be careful again when you have any money changed to look at what you take. I told John William and requested him to look at what I had given him and he came tonight to say they are all right.

Ann has been writing to Mary today. The letter is waiting for me to take in the morning. It seems lonely not to have George come and go and bring the mail. He is gone where he was before and I do not know when he is expected home (Anna says tomorrow) Jane had a letter from Turin Friday. Maggie keeps about the same - not gaining - Jane means to go to see her and Clara wrote to inquire if she can get there if she goes up on the cars. She was in church Sunday she was very sorry not to have heard you the Sunday before but she was sick abed so that neither she nor Clara could go. I have heard several speak of how well you did. I thanked Wm. Thomas for what he had given you and said we had not expected so much. He said it was all right that you did very well indeed - John D. told Gwen you did splendid. She told me and she said she had seen him talking with you a little before - so she asked him if he had told you how well he liked your preaching. No, he said - I did not want to spoil him - we all are too apt to get proud! Gwen enjoyed the sermon very much but she did not feel quite sure whether you did not give Satan too high praise when you spoke of him as omniscient! She believes he knows a great deal is full of all mischief but does he know everything?

Wednesday 8-15 a.m. Another beautiful day. I am starting to the villages and will see what I can do for Rev. E. Davies tho I am not very helpful. I forgot to say anything about your ordering the spring suit. It is growing warm so you will be feeling the need of it. We think you had better do as you deem best - as to which cloth to choose - Mr. Williams will advise and help you select - we think he can tell better than we. Mary Evans charges $1 for making pants. Suppose you ask what difference it will make in the coat if you have the pants made by her. Please write before the week is out to your loving aunties J. & A.L.E.

Home. Apr. 30, 1885

Dear J.E.

  We received your letter last evening. We are always glad to get your letter, as you know, and hope you will not forget us each week.  Have you written to your father yet since going back to college? I hope you have. We are very glad of the encouragement you get from Mr. Grove, and sincerely hope you may do well with your declamation — I mean what piece are you going to speak? Using plain old fashioned language. My dear boy, I trust and pray that your education may be

made a blessing to you, and a great many others through you.  Have we told you that Jennie is helping Mr. Davies with the May number of the Cenhadwr?  She has been going down now every day for about a week, and coming home at night.  She says she rather enjoys the change, and I hope she will not feel any worse for it. The walking has been so bad that it has been rather hard for her to go back and forth, but it is better now — though not very dry yet. I went to the woods day before yesterday while she was gone and brought home a tiny bunch of spring beauties — the first we have had this year. I enjoyed the walk and the

flowers. Your money slips away pretty fast, doesn’t it? Have you paid anything on your board bill this term? we would like to know how that stands. I am very glad your clothes suit you so well.  Can you wear the others on wet days to save them. Will your green suit do to wear for awhile yet? We will send $5 in this to pay the tax that you speak of — please drop a card when you receive it. When Jennie first communicated with Mr. D. she asked him if he had heard anything from Mr. Greshan and he said he had not - she has not spoken to him of it since.  She expects they will finish setting the last form today. Much love from your loving aunts. J. & A.L. Everett     Over

We heard from Mary two or three days ago— she talks of coming home soon — said she might possibly come this week, but we do not expect her so soon. The Turin cousins are all getting well of the measles. Carroll expected to take a music lesson yesterday.  We have not heard from Maggie lately.  We have not had the maple sugar yet but will try to send you some when it comes.  We shall be anxious to hear that this reaches you safely — if you send a card you need not mention the money, only say the letter was received all right — but be sure and write immediately.  Anna
in margin
We realize that your frequent journeys to and from Utica this term make some differences in your expenses also your new suit, which expense will not have to be repeated very soon again.  This is P.S. No. 2.

Remsen, Nov. 23, 1885
My dear Nephew, It is now so near Thanksgiving that our thoughts are very much of you. Will you be coming home? or what plan have you made for the day? Will there be exercises Friday and Sat? As you will already be in Utica for the Wednesday lessons? it would not be much more expense to come home. We would not wish to hinder you if you have other plans in view but we wish you to know that you would be very welcome here should you come. The walking is pretty

bad, snowy and slushy. John Williams says the roads are unusually bad - so you must expect that. George comes out every night  but did not go down last night. We are sending this with him. It seems long since  we have heard from you. We are looking every night for a letter. G. was out of the village Sat. and did not return till the mail was closed so perhaps there is a letter there from you. Did cousin M. tell you we have heard from your father again. His eyes trouble him with the right one he sees but little, but the left is good. How were they when you were with him? I have

answered his letter. Also have written to Edward. Mary had a letter Friday from Frankie. She is well and expected to begin going to school today. She said she was going to send Mary a present this week - has she written to you yet? How often do you see cousin Josie? Does she go home Thursday? I would like to fill this sheet but fear George will go. A young man from Cazenovia preaches for us next Sab. He is coming home with Eddie Samuel we understand.

  Jane told us yesterday that Piece has a fine little daughter—
  We are usually well and send much love - L?

George bought him a pair of rubber boots the other day & likes them very much.  Rev Mr. Prichard of Rome preached here yesterday.  Mrs. Rachel Price was 83 years of age yesterday the 22nd  I gave Cousin M two dollars to pay for the laces. You can get it of her. I will give you a dollar towards your expenses if you like to come home to Thanksgiving. M.  &A. &I another 

 What did you learn about a stove?  Ask cousin Mary if she can advise you - Look at the one in Fannie's room. I must write to cousin M. Her visit did me so much good!

90 State St Utica, N.Y. 
March 3, 1883  
My dear Nephew,  We have had nothing from you as yet but hope there will be a letter today.  The storm Saturday night began as we were going to bed, before you could have reached Clinton we think. We have thought a good deal the long uphill walk you had carrying your heavy satchel and facing the cutting wind. Hope you did not take cold. We shall be thinking and praying for you tonight  It is the evening for some to speak to that little mission church  Did you have any difficulty in getting excused for your absence coming home?  and how did you get along in your classes?  Anna wishes you to send the measure of your mantle piece  the outside and ends for a lambrequin  Also that of the top of your bureau

We find all very kind here and Anna is getting nicely rested. She and cousin M. went to the greenhouse just below here a short-time yesterday. She came back much refreshed and Cousin M. brought us? very sweet pretty flowers. I have not been out yet  It was so rainy Sunday and wet yesterday also  The snow seems dryer today and I know the walks will be such that I can call at cousin Lewis' and perhaps go down street - Fannie has to go so I should have company.  The mail has just come without bringing anything from you - hope no news is good news this time.  I know you must be very busy after losing so much time. After writing the above sentence it has come to my mind that there is a letter from you - It is addressed to Anna and Fannie has taken it upstairs to her as she is lying down after breakfast.  So I have not read it yet.  There was a letter forwarded from Edward.

and the Washington letter Cousin M.A. Roberts, Chicago, also sent a card to Cousin M. asking if she can arrange to receive her for a short visit- She hopes to come about the 12th or 13th inst. It will be pleasant for us to be together for the visit - cousin M. says If you should come down while she is here you might sleep at cousin Lewis'  I guess   There they have brought your letter for me to read   I am very glad you succeeded so well with your essay  I thought it was to be tonight.  It was too bad you had so little time to prepare.  Go over it again and make it better and you may be very glad to see? it sometime in our neighborhood  It must have been pretty driving business to prepare it. Hope you will not often be obliged to miss going down to your breakfast.  I think I should enjoy the walk with you Take good care of your health always We got along all right and did not need you to help us Saturday evening  You know

the cars brought us to Cottage St, and it is but a short and very pleasant walk from there I felt easier than to have you hurried in coming up with us.  Ann glad you got the stationery  Shall expect frequent letters I have no idea yet when I will go to Hillsdale  Must make inquiries and write there first  Wonder if we are to have cheap fares! Edward writes that Carroll is preparing to be examined by the School Commissioner - not that he is old enough to teach They have had a letter from G. P Jones Emporia He does not advise them going to Kansas just at present  The times are dull   The last they heard from Maggie was Friday She was a little better very weak still  I must try to write to your father today - also to Mary - so must leave - this with bushels of love  no signature

Remsen June 3, 1887  
My dear Eddie  
Yours was received yesterday and we were very glad to hear from you so promptly.  Anna asked me to write instead of her as she has already written a letter to cousin Mary and is feeling somewhat tired.  Cousin M is at Carlton Island and we had a short letter from her there two days ago. Clarance was feeling better after going there. 

  Yesterday Jane and Maggie were here - M came home with her mother last Tuesday and expects to return Tuesday next

We had a very pleasant visit with them.  Mrs. Jones Cobin was also here to tea.  She came with me from church meeting and as there came up a very strong thunder shower she stayed till it was over.  Maggie stopped an hour or so after her mother went to have a longer visit with us.  Then she went to meet her mother to Dr. Price's and from there they were going to the cemetery to set out some plants. 

  I came home Monday before G. Jones got back from the village.  Was very sorry not to see you but hope it will not be long before you come again.  How

soon does your term close?  Mary is going to the village and it is most dark so I must not hinder her.  We are usually well - had a nice rain or rather rains and vegetation is starting nicely.  Shall hope for a letter from you soon - How does your declamation prosper?  Your loving aunt  J. Everett

Remsen, Feb 24, 1862, 
Dear Robbie, 

  There is such a storm that nobody can go with Frank's letter to the office tonight and so I'm going to write a little to you. What do you say to that? Would you like a letter too? How much better it would be if I could only see you and have a nice talk with you and tell you stories? Do you like to hear stories? your cousins Robbie and Onie do very much. Onie is not very well now, he has been pretty sick with a cold, but he is better now. Yesterday he went with his papa and mamma to his grandpa Williams and your Aunt Anna and I went

down to your uncle Lewis to stay with your cousin Robbie and Maggy. We had a nice time, little Maggy was very good and so was Robbie. After we had been there a while I went to the book case to look for a book to read, Robbie came and stood on a chair by me. He looked at me quite a while as I opened one book and there another and put them back - at last he offered his advice and printed to a book, which said was "the best book", It was a patent Office Report it did not seem to me as though it would be very interesting nor get quite the kind of book to read Sunday. So I laughed a little at Robbie's selection and told him that I did not think it would be right to read it Sunday. He looked very sober. He did not like to have me laugh at him. So to please him I took it down, and sure enough, it was a good book for little boys and girls. It had a

host of pictures in it, Robbie wanted to know if I thought it would be wrong to look at them Sunday. I said no, and so we took the book out into the kitchen and sat down to look at them, Maggy came and sat on my lap and Robbie sat on a chair by my side. There were pictures of cows, and sheep, squirrels, and mice and ever and ever so many kinds of birds. We had a very nice time looking at them. Among the rest we saw a king bird with a bee in its mouth. Robbie wanted to know, why it had got the bee. I told him that they were what it had to eat and that his grandpa used to have bees his papa would try to kill every king bird he could find. But what what makes the king bird eat the bees? asked Robbie again, what makes you eat bread and butter, said J. because I. Because I like it, said Robbie smiling.

and that is for me to eat. And can you tell me now why the king bird eats the bee, I asked. Yes, they like them, and that is what is for them to eat, he replied. After a while we got tired of looking at pictures and Robbie wanted to hear something about his cousins Frank and Robbie. He loves dearly to talk about you and he would be very glad to show you his pictures and every thing else pretty he has if you would only come out here. I asked him what I should say to you when I wrote to you. "O, tell them we have had four little bossys and that papa had to kill them all but one because he didn't have enough milk for them and they would die if he didn't kill them. But we have got one bossy a great deal younger than Maggy and its got great large teeth," - when we were getting supper Robbie told us where to find everything. I wonder if we should go to your house some day and your mother was not a home, whether you could tell us where to get something to eat. Do you think you could. Now, when Frank writes you write to Aunt Jennie

Remsen, March 24, 1863
My dear Frank,
We were very glad to get your letter tho' it was so short. How is that pretty little brother of yours by this time and how is your mother? O dear, how I wish we could see you all! Or if we cannot see you I wish we could get your likenesses. Is there no chance to have them taken in Osawatomie or any other place not too far off for you to go to get them. If you will get them taken and send them to me I will send money to pay for them. I am so afraid you will get to be a great big man, and Robert and baby too, before ever

I see you. You were a little bit of a fellow when I saw you last in Utica. Your dear uncle Robert was living then and he and I went with you down to the depot to start you off.
Yesterday afternoon your uncle Lewis, aunt Jane, and three little cousins were here. Would you not have enjoyed being here with them? They are dear little children and I know you would like them. We have a little calf, two days old now, and the children were pleased enough with it. Maggie's mamma thought it was most too cold for such a little girl to go out and see it. So Maggie got the comb and parted her hair like a little boy and then she thought she might go as well as the boys. So she was bundled up and aunt Anne carried her out to see the calf. When she came in she told me the calf

did not have any horns and that it was red with a white back and that the old cow was all white.
When Anna and I were in Utica we got Maggie a set of little dishes and if you and Bobbie would come to see her she would make you a cup of tea in them. She made her Grandpa some the other day when she was there.
Tell your mother that we did get that $3.00 all safe and that we have got rennets ready to send and are only waiting to know what other things she wants sent with the rennets. I have written to her about it and I hope she has had the letter before this.
We have had a good deal of snow lately and the roads are bad now. The weather has been warm for two or three days now - Write again soon. We all send love. Your aunt Jennie.

undated, apparently wartime
Dear John, Will you not write and let us know particularly how Sarah and the baby are and how you all are?  When was baby born?  Frank's letter was quite too short.  I am sorry you have been so uneasy about that $3.00.  I ought to have acknowledged it sooner than I did.  I hope you have had my letter tho' now that I shall soon hear from you what things to send.  I had to give 20 cts each for rennets.  That is what farmers here get for those of deaconed calves mother think those we were getting from Uncle will be much better.  They were dried last Summer. Last Tuesday John P. Jones (H. P. Jones' son) was buried.  He died in the hispital in Washington and yesterday father attended the funeral of another young soldier, John Hughes.  Friday last, Morris, the youngest son of John R. Griffiths was buried.  There have been a great many deaths about here the past year.  We are in usual health.  Sister Jennie

South Hadley, March 16, 1852.
Dear Sister Margaret:
I have I feel followed your example too closely and delayed this much too long Would that I could excuse myself so completely as you. I know I might plead many duties to occupy my time, but there were some little 'odds and ends' that I might have employed in answering your letter. I will therefore "Lock the dead past bury it dead" and saying no more about it hope to be more prompt in future. You were much mistaken in supposing we had no school Christmas. The holidays were past so much as other days that they might have passed without our knowledge, and we have entered the new year all unconcious, had not Mr. Hawk mentioned it at devotions that morning. I thought of you much that first day of the year and of Ellen. I should like to write her a letter of advice, but, Margaret, how can I? I know nothing of that tumultuous sea on which she has embarked. I cannot warn her of the shoals and quicks and nor of the rocks which be concealed by a little water, for I know not where they are. You, Margaret, have explored it a little way and are much better qualified than I

to direct her in the right course. Give my love to her and my warmest wishes that hers may be a happy voyage darkened by no storm.- It seems a long, long time since I left my home and home friends dear, and many weeks yet must be passed before I see them. How sweet the thought that in that bright world above these will be no parting, distance will be annihilated. Oh, may we all meet there.- This morning before the Sun had raised his head from "the lap of Thetis" the little birds sang sweetly. Spring has come at last, the snow is mostly gone and the grass begins to grow. The roads have hardly got settled yet, though we have had some delightful walks upon the soft turff by the roadside. I love the spring with it soft and mellow breezes, It whispers to the trees and they put forth their green leaves, the earth too hears its voice and up springs the tender grass and lovely flowers.- I hope to find Sarah pretty well when we go home. We had a letter from her last friday evening. She was still fast improving and had begun to stand up. Said she has lately received a letter from you and that Lewis wrote a "few words" in it. May we not too hope to see a "few" marks of his pen in your next? (How do you get along with your store? Do you think of going to N. York again next fall? If so I wish you could go so early that we might have your company back when we go home. My health is pretty good now. I have the rest of the sheet for Mary. When will Hespareth? leave that we may have that "long letter" from Lewis? I was sorry to hear by mother's letter that your sister May is sick. Give my love to her and to all your father's? family and accept a good share yourself. Write soon your aff. sister Jane

Hudson, Dec, 1. 1855.
Mary:
Your letter should have been answered sooner had I not just sent one to Cynthia and I have been very busy. I do not get much time to write, during the week. My health is pretty good though I have quite a hard cold just now. The weather has been very unsettled since I have been here, wet and pleasant, cold and warm days, follow each other like smile and tears. This day is very pleasant, Mr. Most, has just failed in business. I do not effect this will have upon me. I hope I shall not be obliged to change my boarding place. I have not said any thing to them about it as it not a pleasant topic for conversation. I shall not trouble myself about it.

for if I remain there is no occasion for sadness and if I leave I shall know it soon enough. I am glad to hear Sarah is so well. When may I expect Cynthia's letter? I have been writing several letters to day and i feel that this must be very short.- There are only three weeks longer of this term. How i wish the vacation could be passed with you at. Then I should look to the close of school with eager delight, now, I wish there was no vacation till summer. I intend to pass the time at Mr. Williams' but I do not anticipate much pleasure, for they are strangers, Yes, yes, I will enjoy myself. I was not thankful when I wrote that sentence, I forgot that they were friends of my parents. 
Some one has called to see me and I must close here. I am sorry you have been anxious about me, I have been troubled a little with my head and did not dare to write for a few days. Jennie

Our Room, March 25, '51
annotation  1857   /annotation
Sister Mary:

 It is such a rare thing for me to have a letter from you that I must answer without delay.

Ellen Jones, Morris Roberts' daughter, is to be buried today. I have therefore no school. I thought once of going down to Utica today, but since reading your letter decided to wait till Saturday, when I hope to meet you there if you are able to do so. Father was very anxious that as much as could be should be done by private sales before the public sale. Thomas has therefore disposed of some things and will of more if he has an opportunity. Lewis went down with the sleigh last Saturday and brought  
top margin

I hope your head is better by this time. What did Dr say about your leaving so unceremoniously. Do you think your visit home did you harm? Elizabeth wishes to know whether you are not going to make them that visit. Mr. Ricker expects to go that way during the season and perhaps you might go with him and I would go after you. What would you think of that? 

Eddie does much better this term than last. He is getting along very well. Lizzie says all the men she has to unclear is unclear
side margin
Lizzie does not like to have her love crouded into so small a place so I will put some more of it here.

up both sofas. I thought the red one might be covered and be very comfortable for us in the kitchen- There, ma had just come up and she says she wrote to you yesterday and told us all about this. So you will please pass over this second entry.
The gives are all pretty well Sarah is just now lying down to rest her. She came up to rest before washing the floor and soon there came up word that she need not trouble about the floor as it was mopped. It did not seem long enough just to have got things ready but ma does things so quick when she attempts it. Will every any of her daughters be so smart? 
Lettie is writing us, She talks of learning a trade. If Miss Roberts can take her she will go there.
Lizzie has called to see about it

but received no decided answer. It would be pleasant in many suspects if Lettie could be with her. She could spend her Sabbath with us and we could take a little charge of her. She has no desire to return to school at Whitsetown. She has learned Grecian painting and Sarah has commenced to take lessons of her. I hope you will not fail to learn Oriental painting. We are quite anxious to learn it. I think now I shall try to rest this summer and if so I shall have a fine time for such things. Pierce Williams has engaged the District School in the village for this summer. He will commence very soon so we shall be seeming opposition. Wonder who will have the most scholars. Only a few nights since I dreamed that a very tall Spanish

gentleman had taken that school and was popular that he soon got all my young ladies. Anna talks of making a trial of his school. I am almost afraid he is the Spaniard of when I dreamed. He would like to board with Lewis but they have not yet decided.- Cousin Mary expects to go to house keeping next May and then we shall lose Lizzie .
This will be quite a disappointment for me as I had calculated a great deal on her company this summer.
Thank you for the address of Rev. Mr. Cook.- Remember me to Charley Fowler. I should like very much to see him. What standing has he as a scholar? he has good abilities and I should be happy to learn that he is making good use of them.
What a pity Mrs Sanford is not a gentleman and a bachelor, it would be so romantic. As it is I am quite thankful for her first impressions. Respects to her and your "Graefenberg mother" Love Jennie 
side of letter
In company with this I send a letter to Elizabeth. We received a letter from her Monday night. Heard from John last week. They are all well and in fine spirits. Their letter was written before Gov. Geary resigned. The prospect of Kansas being a free state looks rather dark to us now.

Smith's Hotel, Saratoga Springs  
Oct. 29, 1858  
Dear Sister Mary,  There was no address to your little note but as all the rest was to Sarah I take it that it was meant for me and accordingly answer it.  Thank you much for all the cheerful words you write about our dear mother.  It is hard for us not to be with her now.  Do use all your influence to keep her from being too smart.  I do wish just now ma had a little more of her daughter Jennie's laziness for indeed it is of the utmost importance that she should keep still.  Do, dear mother, try to imagine you are
crosstext
Dr. often asks very kindly for you.  You have succeeded in some way to make him set a pretty high value on your little self.  I do believe he thinks you are equal to Sarah and me put together ie. you are good as Sarah and jolly as I and smart as both of us.

me for a week or so and take it easy. A sprain is so much worse than a broken bone because we can use the limb and we want to all the time and it seems to me to be very hard not to yield to the temptation and do a great deal of injury if not prevent it from ever being quite strong. You girls ought to be permitted to try your hands at housekeeping for a little while. Who knows the incalculable benefit it may be to you at some future time? How glad we are to know you are so smart. Try and be careful, sister dear, that you may continue to grow strong. If you are prudent I do hope you will be well yet and do your part in the work of life. Remember that "an ounce of preventative

is better than a pound of cure." I too hope again to be well or at least so that talking will no longer be a burden to me. We are both doing very well Dr. says. He is quite sanguine in regard to both of us and it would not become us to be discouraged. Tell pa I hope he will miss me a little about mailing, it does us good to feel that we are missed at home. I believe no "cordial" could have accomplished the wonders that Anna's dear letter has. I do believe it is more than half true what Dr. Fowler said about my loving to have my friends express their affection. Words of love are food for the heart and Anna's letter has been to me a continual feast.  Little Robbie has

not forgotten Aunt Jennie. Tell him she wishes she could have "peeled his apple." Kiss him and Arnie for us and tell him we often talk about him and wish very much to see him.
We are having very pleasant weather now. The mornings are just cool enough for brisk walking and the rest of the day for promenading the streets quite fashionably, Sarah has finished her letter to Anna and is now busy at work on her stocking She has had quite a mania for tape trimming and has made I can't tell how many yards, I shouldn't wonder if she would be putting it around pillowcases and sheets &c. when she gets home. Thank Anna for sending that collar. Love to all - Sarah wrote to Elizabeth the other day but has heard no answer yet. Write another little letter to Jennie.

annotation  Jane Everett /annotation

                                    Mountain Parsonage, 
                                                         May 23, '57

Sister Mary,

         Thank you for your kind letter which I received last evening and the suggestion. I hardly know what to do in regard to it. Were Mrs. Holland to apply to me, I think, from your representations, I should be happy to accept the situation. As nothing has been said by her to me or you /so far as I know in regard to engaging me, I had not given the matter any serious thoughts. The school in which I am now is, as you know, a very laborious one, owing to my having the case of every thing and I feel that it is taxing my strength more than I can a long time endure. This and the face that I should have a much better opportunity for greater influence, for good where I should be more with my pupils than is possible in a day school

lead me to wish to be engaged in a boarding school. What Sabbath privilige have the pupils, and is there daily family worship which they attend in the Dr's family? I believe you said there were only to be young ladies in the school next year did you not? Are there pretty good prospects for the next year? I might ask you many other questions which I would wish to know but I have not the time. Please write by return mail if only a few words and tell me whether you or Mrs. Sanford think I had better apply or wait a little for Mrs. Holland. 

   We are all in usual health, Mother has had a lame back and then a pain in her side but is now better though not quite well. We miss Lizzie very much. Lititia is succeeding very freely with her dressmaking, I should not much wonder if we should keep her busy all summer as we have a great many more dresses to be made. 
   Did Miss Pope visit you. She came

up here the Saturday that Anna was at Utica and staid till she returned hoping that you would come also. 

  You do not say how you are now. Hope you are still gaining. We should be very much delighted to see you once more at home. When may we expect you, this term closes next week and then we shall expect to have a regular time housecleaning Anna thinks of spending the vacation at Uncle Henry's that she may take a few music lessons. By the way, Uncle was up here yesterday and he said that he some expected Uncle Nathaniel over this summer on a visit.
  O, dear, Anna and Sarah have come for this letter and I must close that Eddie and Georgie may take it to the mail. Georgie Manuel has been here to day visiting Eddie and a fine time they have had.
   Give my love to Mrs. Sanford and thank her for the interest she has taken in my welfare. Take good care of yourself, Mary, dear, and don't get overexcited about getting me a place.

Remsen Jany 1, 68–
Dear Mary

 I am afraid you are short of funds. - and if so - and your head troubles you too it is too bad -
 We send here in three drafts by –

7 50  
13 85
20.-
bracket 41.35
Hope you won't have much trouble in getting them cashed - 
Be sure dear daughter to let us know when you need more - - 
Jennie will write a few lines in this –    Your father RE.
Dear Sister, Father wishes me to write a little just to ask you how you are - we are very busy as you can well understand when I tell you we are to have a Donation next week Wednesday, and Sarah is sick - we hope she will be better in a day or two - she got the garret all cleaned out

last week but we have not done much else towards getting ready. I will have to try to get all the time possible to set this week as it will be pretty late in the month you see when the Donation is over to begin on the Cenhadwr then.  Yesterday morning baby complained of sore throat - he was quite poorly all day - was very restless all night last night - feels a little better this morning after being dressed - we hope it is nothing but an ordinary cold but we feel more uneasy than if Robbie Henry had not just had this scarlet fever.  Anna is feeling pretty well now also father and mother - and the rest of us well. Lewis and family are well again.  We had a letter from Eddie  a short time since also from E. and Hattie - they were all well - E. had lost your address and so could not answer your letter till we send

it to her.  Mr. P was from home last Sabbath week and he goes to Plainfield next Sunday. He was with us yesterday and preached in our church last evening a very good sermon which I wish you could have heard.  It is so nice here now that he does not use tobacco - He is greatly improved.  Tell cousin Tom and ask him if he will not try to follow his example - that is the only fault I think my cousin Tom has.  Father says that if your head continues to trouble you perhaps you had better come home for a little   We should all be very glad to see you, you know that without my writing it - but your know best what you ought to do.  Thank you, dear Mary very much for the trouble you took on my behalf.  I am glad to know what you think about that Dr.  I am very much inclined to try him.  I had concluded before getting your letter that it might be scrofula that was the cause of my trouble.

but I really do not think that I took cold that brought it on.  I do not think that I had a severe cold once that year I was in Ohio.  I think now it came on gradually perhaps caused by overexertion.  &c.  We have his treatise and that was what made me think so about my ears - you know I often have rough hands - and my ears are often dry and scaly and then my hearing is much worse - but I will try to write to you again about this.  I have no more time now if this goes off this morning.  Will be glad if you can learn more about him.  In John's last he says that his hearing has been quite bad of late. - Much love  Jennie your Sister

It seems to me that I am owing you a letter but I have been too busy with necessary duties to think of collecting bills even, to say nothing of the more disagreeable business of paying my debts.  This morning however we saw the Cenhadwr once more leave us and we have a little time to think of something besides that, but it is so warm that there is little energy to our thoughts.  Cousin Mary very agreeably surprised us last evening by coming into the office where we were busy with covering - of course she meant to go to Turin this
in margin  
He thinks there is to be a high school in Remsen this winter and that makes him feel a desire to stay and go there.  This morning I gathered the apples from the tree near the grape vine - about a peck in the crab apples ought to be picked too if only we knew what to do with them - out pie apples are nice for cooking now.  It must be about time for black berries now - this must be a busy month for us as it is the time for our Cymanfa.  I am sorry Mrs. Jones cannot come to the meeting.  I saw Mrs. Griffiths Cincinnati in church a week Sunday

time and have to go with her but Mary Jane is sick and wants to leave tomorrow.  she told us so first last Monday.  What we shall do without a girl I don't know - but this is clear to me - it will not do for me to leave home now.  Anna is very much worn, and she really needs a little recreation - so , if possible, I wish to persuade her to go with cousin Mary.  Otherwise I fear Mary will go back to Utica without visiting Eddie after all  This morning she and Anna walked down to Lewis'.  Anna meaning to go to capel Isaf to the funeral of another daughter of Rev. E. Humphreys, the one that married Robt Prichard's brother - and this afternoon mother and John Eddie went in the buggy after them - Wm

has been sleeping on the lounge and Mary Jane on the bed upstairs - so I am lonely enough to write - Wm has steped out some where just now. He does not yet to feel at all well - tho' we think he is a little better than when he first came home. Frank is down to Lewis' also today helping Robbie with the barley - tonight they intend going to camp meeting which began last Wednesday. Mother received Mary's letter this morning - shall be anxious to hear again soon We are wanting very much to see you all. I cannot tell what to say to you about your arrangements for the winter only I should not advise you to have Kate Hughes again - you know what I saw of her was not altogether agreeable - and Wm says you have

a very good Kate now and I hope you will be able to keep her - if you need any one else, could you not get a good Welsh girl? I do not know what we shall do with the Cenhadwr - nothing definite has been arranged. While we publish it as we do I do not see how I can be spared from home - what does Sarah think she and William will do? If she were home perhaps Anna could be spared for a while, but I do not know - there is a great deal to be done and seen to and, O Mary, it is so hard without father to advise about things, 
Frank told William that he did not mean to stay here this winter - John Eddie is quite a comfort to us but we are anxious he should be going on with his studies - he does not want to go back to New York - what course do you think we ought to take with him

Remsen, Oct. 4, 1870
Dear Mary,
I've a mind to write you a short hasty note today instead of a longer letter in a day or two. We are using our spare moments now trying to save what we can of these pie apples. Every morning we try to cut what we can take care of to dry about the fire during the day. There are very few if any of them quite sound, and we will soon have to dry or stew those that are not already fresh hope (sic). I fear they will not do to make jelly - we mean to try those strawberry apples for that. -I do not wonder those pie apples were not

not good for much by the time they reached New York, am glad the Tallman sweets stood it better. 
We had quite a time getting the Cenhadwr off and preparring for meeting, but just when it was nearly time to begin to look for the ministers to come out of meeting (about three o'clock) and we were not nearly ready for them our good friend Carrie Griffiths came in. She said that they knew we must have a great deal to do and as they were nearly through she came to help us - and truly she did help.- She mopped, cut apples, made pies &c. and all the rest of us seemed to work easier after she came so that by tea time all was in apple pie order, and all went to evening meeting except Anna and I - no one came to stay

with us that night and in the morning we got off the Cen. nicely.
Our friends from Floyd came as usual before morning meeting - we did not have many to dinner or tea and we have had no baking to do since. Eddie was delighted with his coat and father liked his hat very much - it is a little bit snug for him but I believe not uncomfortable.
Father, mother and Sarah went to Bethel meeting and father and mother to Rome. They had a wet day in Rome but good meetings and were not sorry they went. In coming home they stopped at Uncle Henry's and found there a photograph for ma of Rosa and one for Elizabeth - ma brought E's home and left ours for a little with cousin Mary.
Anna went to the meeting

the last evening and enjoyed it much and was none the w- she stood all the worse for going - she stood all the hurry and bustle remarkably well.
We expect to have prayer meeting here tonight if the weather permits - It was very rainy yesterday but today so far it does not rain - yesterday Lewis went for apples and got two barrels for us.
Father and mother think of going tomorrow to attend the Waterville and Plainfield meetings - all well and send love. Remember me kindly to Mrs. Jones and all others who may enquire kindly for me. I saw Jennie Thomas at the meeting - she is visiting in Remsen - Hastily
Sister Jennie Everett

Remsen, Feb. 15, 1872  
Dear Mary,  
Mother came home on the morning train yesterday.  Carroll was better before they got there and continued to gain.  Yesterday they were going to dress him for the first time since he was taken sick - he slept with his father and mother Tuesday night, slept all night.  The night before his two grandma's watched with him.  Anna remained in Turin - hoping Sara would join her there before she comes home.  Sara has not yet come downstairs - she sat up some yesterday in the arm chair by the dumb-stove  We have had very pleasant weather for some time till Tuesday P.M.
in margin  
also died or not.  It must be very lonely for Thomas and the rest without Lizzie - what will they do?  I shall never see her again in this world - she was so kind and good that those nearest her must always have loved her most.  We are very glad you were able to be with her some during her sickness.  Last night Robbie could not go for the mail nor this morning - it is snowing some but does not blow much and we hope we can send this down so that it can

it grew windy and like a storm and all night it stormed hard and yesterday, especially in the morning. _ It was so bad that I gave up the idea of going with father to the funeral and Robbie went to drive - but when they got as far as Mr. Pugh's he told father that it was not possible for him to go so they turned back - Lewis brought the children up there in the morning and he and Jane started to go to Penymynydd - when they got to Mr. Pugh's he went with them as far as Rob. Hughes thinking to go up with Lewis and leave Jane at RH. Hughes' - but they gave up and Mr. Pugh went home to watch and tell father that there was no use in trying to go.
Mother had written (or rather Eddie wrote) that she would come on the coming train
in margins
he mailed tomorrow. Tommy is here today thrashing - we do not know who we shall have to work for us next summer. It does not seem as tho' we can possibly get along with Robbie. We want father to ask Tommy but do not know what he will do - I had a letter

the night before to reach Remsen at 8-50 P.M, and Robbie was there to meet her - but she missed the train - so in the morning David Price went with his horse and brought her home - it was very stormy for her to come but we were so glad to see her.
I have been almost sick with a very hard cold for three days - it began in the left side of my head and made me feel as tho' I was breathing needles - and my left eye and ear and temple ached so hard whenever I went into a cold room the first night - I took nux - the next Hipa and last night Bell. - Yesterday and today I have kept a little shawl on my head and a large one on my shoulders except when I sit near the fire - I coughed some last night and today and hope the cold is moving preparatory to leave. Cynthia took the powders you sent
in margin
from John night before last - they are well

one Monday night and one Tuesday I suppose - all day Tuesday her head felt so badly that she could hardly move it - yesterday it was better but fell very lame - this morning she had a spasm and is now on the bed at 11 A.M. Sara came down about an hour ago and is now helping ma get dinner - Mary Evans is here sewing she came Tuesday - she is making up the rep Eddie gave Sis on the Christmas tree for a wrapper. Cynthia thinks she has taken cold and that may be the reason her head has felt so baddly. 

 We have seen nothing of our cousins but Robbie heard that they were expecting to come from Utica on the morning train yesterday and and get off at East Steuben (near French road) and go from there to Penymynydd.  The roads are so drifted that they will hardly be able to come here.
 You do not say whether the baby

Remsen, June 5, 1872
Dear Sister Mary,
Cynthia had another of those attacks today while eating dinner. We all feel very anxious, father especially, that something should be done to check them soon - could you not come home if only for a day or two to see her and then come home in July or when the city grows uncomfortably warm for a longer visit. If you cannot come now without injury to your other patients there in the city what would you think of our trying to have Dr. Gardiner see her? It is near her sick time and it might perhaps be best to have him
in margin
I send this envelop that you may save the time to address another and stamp it. Father sent it once to Utica but it was not used so now I send it to you

come here to see her if he can or one of us can perhaps go to Utica with her if you think it best for him to see her and you cannot come home. These spells seem to wear upon her and we wish so much we knew what to do for her. - Please write immediately.

  Anna is just getting better - she was not very well last week. She is pretty well for her, as they say - and I don't feel very well just now so excuse a short letter.
  Father had a letter from Bro. JJ Jones for the Cen. a few days since - in which there is a puff for you which you ought to see. I expect to set it tomorrow. Father and Mother have gone to Griffith Griffiths to see Mary (James) Jones and husband or rather her husband and herself. Mr. Morris Cadwalader (John Cadwalader's brother) staid with us last night. He preached in our church in the evening but it was so rainy very few were there - Jennie.

Dear Mary, - I find I shall not need have you get that I spoke of for my pultzer bag - the one that I have is perfectly good now that I have cut about an inch from one end. - As to the auricles, I do not know as I can wear them - I put them on to try last evening for a few minutes and I could not see as they helped me much if any. I am sorry you have had so much trouble about them. 

  We had a very severe thunder storm today about 10 A.M. One flash of lightning seemed very near tho' a little west of our house. When John Eddie came from school he said that he and three other of the children felt the shock quite hard. He was near the window and felt it in his breast. Annie and Libbie Thomas were setting with their backs to the stove, and felt it between their shoulders - Georgie Watkins also felt it - how thankful we ought to be that none of them were killed. -  Anna is spending

Remsen June 12/12
First and foremost please write back and tell us whether you would like a black and white striped single shawl, something after the fashion of Sarah's, a little more white in it. We sent to N.Y. with Eddie for a single shawl for Anna and one for me. He got them both black and white striped, and we thought so similar would be most too much at home, and all at once I came across my yellow and white one, which I had forgotten. Anna keeps hers, and Eddie tells us to send the other up to the store, but we delayed, thinking you might like to be surprised with it when you came home, and as you haven't
in margin
the week at John D's with Gwen - Sis and I are going down for the mail and to see how she is after the storm. Please write soon - Jennie

come we want you to send word with Uncle Sam, as soon as you can. We think you have done wisely about delaying to come. I don't remember just how I have been about the unconscious spells. As I was taken with my menses Sat. morning (the day your letter reached us) I have not taken the plat. you sent. Shall I take it now or wait until before the next time? I flowed two days and a half quite freely then stopped wholly, but had just a little coloring yesterday afternoon. I had the attack of which Jennie wrote you know last week Wednes. I think I had been six days without an unconscious spell then, but have had them since something like this, at intervals of about 12 hours for 5 times in succession, commencing the evening before I was taken unwell (Friday) had two Sat.

and two Sunday, have had none since Sun. eve. feel week, but less nervous than usually when I am getting over being unwell.

  Sarah is down flat to-day poor child, is over the worst of it now, has eaten a very little once - has not vomited for the last three times and hasn't had to stay home from church Sundays, but has undertaken it as week day work.
  She likes the specimens of S.S. cards, and would like very much to have you bring the packages home also another bunch of "Words of Jesus" if you can. These you sent she thinks are part 2nd. I have smelled camphor pretty often for the last two or three days, saw that some of us in that wonderful book 
 All send love
   Sis

I have had twitching in the muscles of my left arm when resting yesterday and today -- four or so more words unclear

Remsen April 24/1874

My dear daughter 

  Yesterday your father sent his Bank Book to your Cousin Alexander and requested him to get a draft for 200 dollars on some Bank in New York and send to you, it is from Jennie as her wages were not paid for a great while. you said 150 or 200 if you will need the other 50 you spoke of we may be able to send that next week if you will let us know you would like to have it, I asked Lewis if he could not borrow the money he owed you, he said no father was owing him, but we can not pay him now if father does.

in margin:
We all unite in sending much love to Mrs. Jones. Tell her I should dearly love to go to Wales with her. I hope she will have a pleasant voyage &c.

over it. We are glad you are in good spirits and good health we have been down with bad colds, partly? had to get over it I think Cynthia is weaker after it, but we are all pretty well now I do not know what effect your powder had on her she had one of the old fashioned spasms yesterday morning but she wanted to go with Frank. as he was going for Mary Jane it was stormy but she said she was not afraid of the storm, it was very rough riding as the ground was frozen but she felt pretty well when she came home only tired. after dinner she laid down up stairs, in about an hour

Anna went to see her, and found that she had some kind of a  spell she had bit her toung and was some time a few minutes before she come to 
Dear Mary, — Mother leaves this  for me to add a little, but I hardly know what more to say - you can send me a note for that 200 if you wish to do so, any way, let us know as soon as you can when it is received. We are glad of every bit of description you send about what you are doing in your house. I think Mrs. Jones is right in urging you to furnish ready to let without delay - it is a great rent you have to pay and you ought to have some one in the rooms as soon as possible to help you pay rent. we shall  be anxious about you till your

house is filled any way. When I told Mrs. Jones (Mrs. HR Jones) what you are doing she said "the girls" (her cousins, I think in Utica) "have made a great deal of money  keeping boarders," and she seemed to be quite hopeful that you would do the same. We would like very much to visit you during the year but cannot tell how it will be. I have a pretty hard cold now and it is a  great comfort to have Mary Jane's  help. We are getting along well with Ben, expect to print first side of last form tomorrow. Sara has been having a bad cold and cough. William was down alone to church Sunday and wanted Anna to go home with him, but I was home most down sick and she did not like to go especially as Sara was better.

Remsen, June 20, 1894  
Dear Sister Mary,  

  The enclosed letter from Elizabeth has been here a week or more and ought to have been sent to you before this - please lose no time in answering it.  I feel anxious about Elizabeth's lameness lest it become settled.  I think if I had done something right away when I first found my hearing failing I might have had help and have been saved all these years of hopeless deafness and 

vertical writing 
thing better than Dr. Kingsley's medicine to take.  They do not expect to stay in Glyn another year.  Cynthia and I also made a little visit to Lavinia this month.  It is very pleasant at Eddy's and they were all pretty well - had their loss pretty well covered by insurance.  Eddy was very busy getting things to rights in the store.  Mother and Cynthia still continue to feel the effect of there hard colds in the spring - otherwise we are all well as usual.  John Eddie walked to Glyn this P.M. that He might have a visit and ride with them to church tomorrow.

uselessness — it may be so with Elizabeth if she does not do something now. Your last letter home I have not read - mother thought she showed it to me but I was probably busy in the office or cellar and now  no one knows where the letter is - they say you answered  some of my questions but I may ask them over again as I really want them answered. I feel quite anxious about you these days. What is Miss Griffith able to do to help towards the rent and other expenses? So far it seems that you have to get the  needful when rent becomes due - how much do you

receive from the house towards the rent. When I lent you that $200 I intended to have you have the benefit from it - you have both put your names to it - is it any better for having her name to it - she is a stranger to me, or I would not ask of course. - Mother says that Miss S's sister is still with you helping you sew. What sewing are you having done? and do you expect her to stay all summer? What security have in regard to the house for another year - it will be a great expense for you to furnish the house, fit the carpets &c for only one year or part of a year —

O dear, I wish I could see you and talk things over.  I hope you will not feel vexed at what I have written.  Father and mother intend going to Utica the first of next week to get money to send you against your next rent is due.  We are pretty busy with Cenhadwr.  Lewis printed first side of 1st form today, Anna is reading the pages of other side now.  Yesterday Cynthia and I made Sara and Will a little visit in the afternoon as father had no copy just ready for me.  Sara had taken a hard cold cleaning church Tuesday last but was getting over it.  Wm seemed to breathe pretty hard but said nothing about it.  I wish he could get some-
Writing at top and down left side  
Mrs. Robt James died this afternoon, she has been very sick for about a week.  Mother and father went Tuesday to see her - she was some better than the Dr. thought.  Dr. Wiggins attended her.

without umbrellas and got wet to the skin, sopping west, so that all three of the Griffiths girls had to change their clothing there - the sheds in the village were full when they got there so they could find no shelter from the rain.  Thos. Evans' people were also among the happy (?) partakers of the huge Muche?.  We have been having a rather cold snap - today it has grown warmer and I have no doubt that there was a large attendance on the camp grounds.  Yesterday we ironed, baked and canned blackberries - today we churned and - rested.  I also wrote a letter to John.  Frank had a letter from him last night, he was suffering a good deal from a bad boil on his
