foot. Mother also had a letter from Elizabeth - they were well there - term had just opened quite favorably - crops have been very good with them this year and edibles were plenty & cheap. their garden was full of fruit only the peaches failed this year. 

   Well, I suppose you are looking for a word about your house, wish I knew how to advise you if you could get good help -  certainly the best part of the year is to come, and you have earned a good name, it seems - but you can tell better than I how  you could get along with boarders it will be necessary to change more according for board than for rooms - there is so much more waste, you know. - We shall be anxious to hear soon.

Remsen, Apr. 16, 1875  

Dear Mary,  

  We received your letter yesterday morning - are very anxious about you lest you make yourself sick - wish you could get some one to help you for a little while at least.  It is very hard for us to say what we can do - we have made no arrangement.  I have written this morning to see if we can get Davis for a while - we have quite a little set on second form and hope to have the next number out early - then, if possible, Cynthia and I will try to make you that promised visit.  We would like very much to see you and know a little better how it is with you.  The roads are not yet so that we can take the horse to the village.  Cynthia is pretty feeble you know.

vertical writing at top  
was not feeling well and spring is late also with them so it is hard to find food for the cattle &c.  Jennie

Of course you can keep that you got from Mrs. Jones - for a while at least - and we will try to get for you what you need to borrow.  When will you need to have it?  I wish you could get the house off your hands without any great loss as the care is too much for you, but I suppose you cannot do that now.  If Davis comes and gets along well perhaps some light will break in upon us and we will see more clearly what to do.  Mother wrote last Monday to ask Wm D. Williams if he could come the first or second Sabbath in May and preach a funeral sermon - but before he could have got the letter he wrote to her proposing to do so if it should be her wish and asking her to name the Sabbath.  He has not yet replied to ma's letter so we cannot tell which Sabbath he will come.  Snowing again - had a letter from John yesterday - he

Remsen, Sep. 8, 1895.  
Dear Mary,  

  Yours was received last evening and right glad were we to get it especially as it brought good news about little sister, we sent to the village today thinking there might be another from you.  we shall be very glad to hear again and trust we shall soon.  Mother proposes, if Cynthia thinks best, that she should take and use some of her own money now - that would make her feel more independent and maybe she would get well faster.  What is money good for if not to use - and she may never want it more than now.  She could hire some good woman to take care of her

[[vertical writing]  
I have a money order from John and could send Cynthia some if needed

or she could partly hire her and you could partly do the same and perhaps the same person would be able to attend to Sis and do chamber work.  Then when Sis gets well she can earn money fast enough, and we can help her too if necessary.  John Eddie and Frank have gone to camp meeting tonight - they took Lyl and the buggy and promised to come home before the prayer meeting which is held after the general service.  Mother and I are alone now as Anna and cousin Mary are in Turin.  Monday about 1/2 past 9 A.M. Lewis came up to see if cousin Mary and one of us girls would like to go with Jane to camp meeting - Anna says, yes, you go, Jennie, you are just through with

the washing and can go just as well as not.  Jane came for us with their horse and waggon and we had a charming ride - reached the grounds a little before afternoon service.  Saw many old friends Mr. & Mrs. Ames, Mary Ann & husband and George, Mrs. Mitchel & family, cousin Marcia, and I know not how many others.  We got a seat pretty far forward so that I could hear some, but the wind made constant music with the leaves and just after the text was announced, from way up amid the tree tops a little dead branch came swiftly down lighting on the forehead of an old lady who sat a little front of us - it made quite a sensation but did not drive her from her seat - she evidently believed "that lightning never strikes twice

in the same place." Just after the close of that meeting when we were going to attend the missionary meeting, the men began to run and all went pell mell towards where the horses were tied, but before we got there we found a tree had fallen on a large tent and torn it down - no one was hurt.  Sunday night another tree was blown down near the Remsen tent it fell on and demolished a little out house  another tree broke through one of the tents, and landed in a bed between two ladies who fortunately were not injured.  Those who staid for evening service Sunday night were caught in a severe thunder storm - it was very dark and they had a pretty hard time getting home.  Frank & Maggie and I believe Robbie rode with G. Griffith folks

Remsen Oct. 29/75
Dear Sister Mary,
I write you a few lines hastily this morning as William is going to Remsen in a few minutes. Cynthia wrote to you a few days ago, I think, telling you about the only hard spell she had then had after we came home. She had that a week ago last Tuesday night. Jennie, who was the only one with her as it was in the night, thought it was not as hard as she has sometimes had. But she bit her tongue very badly then.

She had no light spells after, though she has been feeling quite poorly most of the time with one thing and another. She has been unwell and her stomache has troubled her more or less. She has been looking rather badly for a day or two and her head felt bad but yesterday afternoon she seemed rather better I thought and Mother William and I went with her to Lewis' to tea. She seemed to enjoy it very much and last evening was quite bright, but in the night she had three hard spells in her sleep. She does not know as she had more than one but she says this morning that she does not know as her head ever felt as badly

as it did in the night. Jennie will add a few words as she can tell you about it best as she was the only one with her. Cynthia has not got up yet, she thought she would try to sleep, so we can not tell how she feels. It is half past nine.
The first was at 10-40 and that was the hardest. She woke me by groaning and instantly she shook violently - she did not seem to cramp or lift her head and feet as she used to do - only perhaps once or twice at the first) She did not froth at her mouth nor roll her eyes but very little for a moment or so at first - the shaking lasted about 5 m. then she lay as if sleeping only her breathing was not natural and she would

now and then chew her tongue a very little - I sat by her 15 m - the n she opened her eyes and asked "what is the matter." I answered by putting out the light and getting into bed. She lay still and I think she slept - in about 1/2 an hour or so she got up and passed urine - Then slept till 1-45 when she woke me by the violent shaking of the bed - she did not open or roll her eyes at all this time - the shaking lasted about 5 m - I sat up only 10 m. this time - She got up in about 1/2 an hour as before, then slept till 4-10 when she had another very like the second. I only staid up 5 m. this time till she lay quiet - then left the light burning 10 m. more while I got into bed that I might not be unnecessarily chilled -

We hope to hear from you soon - the printing press broke yesterday and delayed the Cenhadwr a day - we can not send till Tuesday morning - when may we hope to see Mrs. Jones - I wish she could have come in the summer as it was pleasanter

in margins
then but we will make it pleasant as possible if she will come. Do you ever see Mr. and Mrs. Edwards? All send Love J.S.S.

At the Cenhadwr this morning this has been a very busy month after our return from Turin. Sarah was able to help us Saturday morning but took to her bed before dinner - she has had a harder time than usual - Anna and Wm were up with her in the night Saturday night - and yesterday afternoon she got chilled again and vomited some. She had a good rest last night and is better this morning. You will have heard before this probably of Mrs. Griffiths' death. She had pneumonia Dr. said - Elias Jones
in margins
is coming will make a little more preparation necessary - wish you could be home too. We have not decided what corner to make ready for him - would you think the study would be pleasant - or the little  room at the head of the stairs - Would you make a bed for father in our room or in Sarah's bedroom. Tommy has just called - he is staying at his brother's now - his side troubles him some still - Wm has opened the cellar windows and he took cold and was most ok Friday but took Kinglsey's med. and is pretty well again,

also dead - died Friday after a short illness of inflammation of stomach and liver - he is to be buried today.  Hugh Jones and wife were sitting up with him Thursday night - early in the morning he went over home leaving Mrs. Jones at Elias' - he laid down to rest for a few minutes, as he thought on the lounge without anything over him, and fell asleep. he took cold and is now very sick with pneumonia - John Eddie slept there last night  that if necessary he might go for help in the night.  Mr. Jones is no better this morning - they sent for the Dr. first yesterday.  Mother says, dont hurry about sending that Mrs. Jones has paid you.
in margins 
We had a severe snow storm yesterday and the ground is all white  The spring  unclear have not been so unclear as to open their eyes yet.  We are intending to get a horse and unclear has been looking but has not found one yet.  unclear will hardly do for us - she can help

We did not have yours in time to acknowledge in this number. Sis was sick again a week last Sat. night & Sunday night - had a hard spell both nights - She is quite feeble all the time - feels the excitement caused by the sickness and sudden deaths.  Charlotte Owen and her husband and Fred were in church yesterday that they might go to their mother's grave.  Mrs. Pierce continues quite poorly - she was not able to be at Mrs. Owens' funeral.  Johnnie Evans is getting well - he was very sick about the middle of this last month that they did not think he could recover.  I receive that paper of Groph. but have not taken any - my hand was all well long before I got it.  I had taken some of what we have in the box.  I
vertical writing 

with another horse so that we could get along without hiring the ploughing &c

do not think it will be possible for me to go to the Centennial - Cynthia could not go too, and it would not be just the fair thing to leave her to sleep alone.  I hope you can go, and see for us all.  I want very much to have Anna go, but do not see the way clearly - Johnnie means to go before coming here - the rest, I believe do not expect to go.  We must be very busy getting ready to receive them.  Have we told you that our little Hattie is engaged?  Mr. Nebecker, her friend, is now preaching in Lowville and she has written to ask if we can make room for him too - she would otherwise have to give up coming herself as he intended visiting her at Hillsdale about that time, and she wanted us to see him &c, &c.  He has his theological course yet to persue so they are not to be married just yet - Of course

Remsen, July 14, 1875  

Dear Mary  

  Yours with Cynthia's is just received - we feel sorry to have you give up your house at such a sacrifice - I supposed all the time that your landlord accepted what you paid him during the summer as payment in full for those months and that he thus had no claim upon you.  I also thought the alternative was running your house yourself or letting another do so with your furniture in it giving you the benefit of the same in having your office &c

vertical writing  
seam advances, while mine is smaller - our school will not be likely to continue much longer —

  The dog is just through churning and I must go to make the butter.  Good by, with love, Your Sister Jennie

retained for you.  That you should abruptly give up everything never occured to me.  I fear you will not be able to dispose of the furniture so quickly without great loss - had you not better retain the house and do the best you can for the winter even if you sacrifice a little in your practice  If necessary while Sarah is home with us Anna might and perhaps better had go to be with you for a time - then if you could keep your present girl and get a young girl to help her - with your house full of boarders even you could go through the winter it seems to me and take time to locate somewhere else by spring and also dispose of your furniture advantageously - I should be sorry to have Mrs. Jones lose by you

and perhaps you had better mortgage your furniture anyway if you so not dispose of it without better without.  She and I might hold first mortgages on it, then we would have equal chances.  Consult with her and let me know.  If you need more money now to enable you to go on, let us know, perhaps I had better let you have some - You will lose more in giving up your office now than in Spring and if you keep your landlord feeling friendly when you leave he will help make the change lighter for you.  William looked for the girls some last night and went with John Eddie to the depot - he staid with Mary Ann last night and Laura, our new girl, came up with

Eddie. - Anna and Mary went with them when they went down, to the graveyard and put a silver leaf geranium and two boquets on the grave, and rode back with Eddie - They had a nice visit in Turin and again at John Lewis' in Boonville as they returned -  Friday there was such a heavy storm that they did not come home will Saturday - We had a frost Friday night and a cold Sunday - the weather is mild again and promises well for the meeting which begins today -  We shall be glad indeed to see the girls and hope they will have a comfortable journey.  Their friends here often enquire about them.  Our S. School will be glad to see them but Anna has done so well that her class cannot miss Sarah very much - in grows larger as the

Remsen, Nov 30, 1877

Dear Sister Mary,  

  Can you tell when you last had a letter from home.  I can only remember that I wrote after we got the last letter from you  It seems a long time.  We hope you are not sick.  If you have not written send a postal if no more as soon as you get this.  Mother worries.  Anna went to Utica yesterday morning - she had a letter the night before from Fanny inviting her and we all thought it would do her good.  She has been taxing herself a good deal lately making bills and sending them out.  We are trying to send all and request settlement before the first of Jan next.  I have been helping her some.  Perhaps her going may put us back a 

[[vertical writing]    We have got our butter yet.  What are you paying now?
Sat. morn. Wm is going in the sleigh to the village with this to the office. Edward William Thornton? was buried last Monday. I suppose you will get the Cenhadwr today - Accept much love from all How is Mrs. Jones? 
Jennie Everett

little, but we hope not more than a month.  My head is feeling better and I am able to do more with it.  Yesterday William took mother to meeting, at the same time as Anna went to the cars.  Sarah and I walked afterwards.  John Eddie had gone geologizing.  He and several other boys went to Enlli visit two caves  One of the boys, John James, who lives near there invited them and acted as guide.  The openings J. Eddie says were 7 by 9 in and they had to crawl, pull themselves along on or with their elbows through 2 ft of mud.  In one of the caves they went down a steep rocky way 150 ft without coming to the bottom!  It was rather dangerous in some places J. Eddie says.  I heard today that there is a cave near there whose bottom has never been found.  We do not know whether that was the one.  After the boys came out of the cave they went

with John James to dinner.  If they looked like our boy they must have been a pretty hard looking company covered with mud and rags!  Yesterday after meeting I went to dinner to Laura's - there was quite a little company there, Ellen Price, Mrs. Margaret Jones, Mr & Mrs J R Griffiths and Katy.  It was snowing hard when I came home and I left my hat and borrowed one that would not injure.  Wm met me at our door saying Mrs. Jones had broken her arm.  John Williams had brought her the cider and she was in a hurry to take care of it that she might go to meetings.  She slipped on the board by the door.  Sarah had gone over to stay while J. W. went for the Dr.  He could only get young Dr. Wiggins.  Dr Williams could not come.  His baby is very dangerously burned.  Evan Charles

came right up when he heard and he wanted to take Mrs. Jones down to Dr. Williams.  He did not like to trust the other Dr. but before they started he came.  So Mrs. Jones let him set it - he says the bone is only cracked but the wrist is badly sprained - the left arm.  Her hand is much swelled today  It pained her all night.  Sarah went over this morning and slackened the bandages a little and gave her some urn and acon in water to take alternately.  Dr. did not give her medicines.  I went over through the deep snow the first of the season this P.M. to see her.  Ellen is with her.  She says she saw a sleigh go past this P.M.  We have had a hard storm today, snowing and blowing in real earnest.  It looks wintry indeed.  Will you ask Mrs. Jones for the names of those who pay to her for the Cen?  It will help us to know so that we may not send bill to those who have paid.

Remsen, Feb. 13, 1878.

My dear Sister,

  Mother was greatly relieved to get your letter Monday when John Eddie came home from school. My hand is much better - you had not sent me any of that Psor, before but I have been taking Graph unclear in water. Have taken nothing since Monday. Will take the Psor tonight in water.
  We are sending the rest of the tubs to the village this morning. If William does not have a good offer (28 or 30 ?) he will send them to Ambler Brs by cars. We do not like to have you so much troubled with

selling the butter. Are glad you are succeeding so well with those last tubs. Mother says you are to use what you need in return for your trouble.
We shall be glad to see you whenever you can make it convenient. We are expecting Eddie and family before long. It would be nice if you could meet them here. Eddie writes that he is very well.

  William drove to Utica Monday for a load of feed and came home yesterday and took me with him. I have not enjoyed anything for a long time as I did that ride and my visit at cousin's. Mary went with me over to Uncle's Monday evening. He had been quite sick with dysentery

was some better of that but he looked quite thin and feeble. They were all very cordial and we enjoyed the call. Yesterday Mary went down street with me and we got mother a cashmere double shawl and gloves - both very nice and warm we think. It snowed hard Saturday night and Sunday so that there was snow enough all the way. We went down in little less than three hours and we were about 4 1/2 coming home with the load. Everybody says we have a good horse now. I found Sarah feeling rather poorly when I got home. Today she is on the bed. They were most afraid I would stay for a visit and come in the cars, so they were extra

glad to see me.
We are glad you had such an opportunity to mingle in upper circle of New York and that you enjoyed it. Hope it will help you on a little to get introduced. I have not yet had time to look at your card, so will not return it just yet. We will take care of it. John Eddie says "The next thing we hear about Aunt Mary, she will be visiting about in her carriage, I suppose, but I wouldn't wear a train for anybody."
Write again soon as mother think so much of your letters.
All unite in love -
Your sister
J E

Remsen, March 23, 1898.
Dear Sister Mary,

 Anna was going to write to you but she looked so tired that I persuaded her to leave it along tonight and let me write a little. I have just written to Eddie and copied John's letters for him and it is now nearly nine o'clock so I cannot probably finish this tonight - Sarah is feeling quite poorly She has been suffering for a few days with prolapous of the rectum - so that she can hardly get about. She ironed some Friday and also Saturday - Sunday she and Anna staid home and she kept very quiet, lying down a good part of the day. She has been taking short sitz

sideways in top margin:
clothing and pay his other expences out of his earnings or how? I did mean to do the him myself and not pay very high wages. I must write no more that I may copy one at least of John's good letters for you. 
Your sister Jennie Everett
Accept much love and write soon please

baths several times yesterday and today. She has tried ignatria and mercurious, and now she is taking arnica. She is a little better today.

 Anna and I washed. Saturday it snowed, with a strong wind from the north, today also it has been very cold and stormy so that we did not put out the clothes except a few on the bars - mercury stood this morning 4° above - tonight it is about 20 degrees and cloudy - there were a great many snow birds about today.

I did not come home till Saturday evening as I suppose you learned by Fanny's card. My boil was very sore and painful - it broke Friday morning and is pretty comfortable now. My right hand is quite sore. I have done it up again. I did not have any med. to take while in Utica - since

coming home I have been taking graph. I have not asked Lewis yet to sign that paper. It has been too cold and stormy for me to go there Edward had sent his before I got home. I hope to hear from the others soon.

  Robert Griffith, Cregau?, is to be buried tomorrow. He had been sick a long time. The funeral is to be in our church at 11 a.m. Which of Mrs. Jones' sisters died while you were home? Give much love and sympathy to her please. We know how hard it is to part with our loved ones. O, Mary, pray for me, that I may be kept very near to my Savior. I feel that I need his guidance especially now. I wish to do what is right.
  Tuesday morn.- Yesterday we had a talk with William about what they ought to have for last year. There never

was any definite agreement. Mother gave them money as they asked for it and they kept the account. They have her according to that $102.85 and Jim thinks they ought to have in all $150 That will be more than what we sold of butter, potatoes, &c. Last spring we had to pay a good deal for hay between $30 & 40. I think we will probably have to buy some this spring if the season is late, I do not know what to do for next year - if we pay both John Eddie and Wm and Sarah - what ought we to pay them? I do not wish to make them dissatisfied or give them less than we would others. I do not know what we can do if they leave - We ought to have consulted about this when you were here. Of course we can do nothing yet! What do you think would be fair for John Eddie - and would it be better to have him buy his

Remsen May 6 '78
Dear Sisters 

 Your card just received – I have a very sore boil on my right hand little finger. We began house cleaning last week but I must stop now on account of my hand. Our friends from Hillsdale expect to be here sometime in August Nobody has written anything for dear Mother's birthday – all send excuses. We like that in the Star if my hand gets better I will do what I can but I find it very hard to find time and ability We hope to send the milk to Trenton factory but have 

overwritten:

annotation 1878  /annotation

Home, Sat. May 25. 1878.
My dear Sisters - I think it about time that we open a correspondence - once more what do you think about it? It seems an age almost since we heard from you. I fear you are sick, or something. Please send a Postal if nothing more as we are anxious to hear. - and I know you are looking for a letter from home. - We have been very busy house-cleaning, - and have not taken time to write letters this week. We are nearly through - Caroline has been here helping us. Wm was very sick with Congestion of Lungs about two weeks ago - Dr. Wms. was here three times to see him. he has had Asthma more than usual this spring. When do you think you can come home We expect Johnny Butler and wife about the last of July - and Mr. B. & Hattie sometime in August. We would be glad if you could be here a little before, and stay while they are here.
Written along the side:
We are all pretty well now. but kind of weak - will write again soon.
